journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Bond graph modelling of hydraulic six-degree-of-freedom motion simulator

article-meta.aff: 2School of Mechatronics Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, China
3Department of Media Technology and Art, Harbin Institute of Technology, China

author-notes.corresp: Qiang Zhao, Traffic College, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, China. Email: zhaoqiangmvp@163.com

abstract.p: Stewart-type six-degree-of-freedom motion simulator is a multidisciplinary system containing multiple mechanical, hydraulic and electric components. This article proposed a unified bond graph representation for the simulator. First, dynamics equations of the upper platform are developed using Newton–Euler method and its bond graph model is established. Each hydraulic actuator is then modelled according to the three basic equations of valve-controlled cylinder. An equivalent approach is further employed to treat the inertial effects of each cylinder. This approach projects the forces caused by the cylinder inertia equivalently onto the joint point of the upper platform, which relatively simplifies the modelling of the piston and the tube. The whole simulator takes independent close-loop position feedback control on each valve-controlled cylinder actuator. A proportional controller with dynamic pressure feedback and feed-forward compensation is proposed. The bond graph model of the overall simulator is finally completed with 20-Sim software, and further simulations and experiments are carried out to verify the model. The model provides another reference for motion simulator modelling besides the multibond graph approach.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Hydraulically actuated motion simulators are widely used in various motion simulating fields, such as vehicle, ship and flight simulators. As schematically shown in Figure 1, a hydraulic Stewart-type simulator consists of a movable upper platform with a simulating cabin on it, a fixed base platform and six parallel hydraulic cylinder actuators. Each hydraulic cylinder is connected to the base platform and the upper platform through a universal joint and a spherical joint, respectively. The upper platform is able to realize a six-degree-of-freedom (DOF) motion when actuated by the six cylinders under control of six servovalves. Figure 1.
Sketch of a six-DOF motion simulator.

As a multibody system, the simulator includes 13 rigid bodies: the upper platform, six pistons and six tubes. Various methods have been used in its inverse dynamics analysis, such as Newton–Euler approach,1 Lagrangian equation,2 virtual work principle3 and generalized momentum approach.4 Based on these methods, the forward dynamics model can be built for simulation. A simulation model with Matlab SimulinkTM was established for a flight simulator in Sirouspour and Salcudean.5 However, the inertial effects of each cylinder were ignored in this model. Koebebakker set up a block diagram model for an overall flight simulator, which considered the inertial effects of the cylinders,6 and a linearized model is used to represent the hydraulic actuator. Actually, each hydraulic actuator is a nonlinear system, including the flow nonlinearity of the servovalve, and the parameter variation caused by the time-variable volume changes of the two chambers of the cylinder along with the piston’s motion.7,8 Generally speaking, the overall simulator model is a typical multidisciplinary nonlinear system involving multibody system dynamics, hydraulic actuation system dynamics, and electronic part and controller dynamics. Bond graph modelling method, devised by Paynter in 1959,9 is capable of describing various energy domains and presenting a unified representation for mechanical, electronic and hydraulic elements.10,11 Using of bond graph modelling tool, 20-Sim software,12 makes it possible to easily establish the overall model of a simulator. The model also presents a full description to various nonlinear factors in the system by means of the powerful extensive function of 20-Sim software.

As regards to bond graph modelling of mutibody system, there are many research works done in this field. Some early pioneering works are as follows. Tiernego and Bos presented the bond graph modelling of robots based on rigid body assumption.13 Zeid and Chung established a library of bond graph models for three-dimensional (3D) joints.14 Zeid and Overholt further put forward a new singularly perturbed explicit modelling method.15

Multibond graphs, as a vectorial extension of one-dimensional bond graphs, are further introduced to the modelling of multibody system.16 In multibond graphs, single bonds have been combined into a so-called multibond. Bond graph elements including energy storage elements, resistors, transformers and gyrators are all extended into multiport elements. In modelling the 3D motion of a rigid body, the 1-junctions standing for the components of the velocity in the x-, y- and z-directions, respectively, are combined into an array of 1-junctions, which stands for the velocity vector. Similarly, 0-junctions standing for forces are also combined into an array for the force vector. These extensions can simplify the general structure of all bond graphs by providing a more concise and clear presentation. The most important is that the multibond graph methodology presents a systematic approach to model rigid bodies and various types of joints and to easily assemble them into complete system model.

Borutzky detailed the multibond extension method of basic bond graph elements, and the multibond graph modelling of a freely moving rigid body and various types of joints, which makes the multibond modelling to be a straightforward systematic method for multibody system.9 He also discussed the use of Lagrange multipliers and another optional relax constraints method to handle causal paths between inertia ports caused by kinematic constraints and presented a three-step procedure for deriving a reduced set of equations of motions from the multibond graph and meanwhile based on the joint coordinate method.

Felez et al.16 mainly discussed the important zero-order causal paths (ZCPs) problem in the multibond graph modelling of multibody system. They presented two different methods to solve the ZCPs. With the first one, Lagrange multipliers are introduced using new flows and efforts as break variables of causal paths to add constraint equations. With the second one, break variables are used directly to open the ZCPs. And accordingly, they developed several algorithms to obtain a set of differential–algebraic equations and solved it using a backward differential formulae (BDF) numerical method.

Yıldız et al. represented a dynamics modelling of a generalized Stewart platform by bond graph method.17,18 A spatial visualization method is developed based on classic vector bond graph method. By transforming inertia elements of dependent velocities to the ports of independent velocities, the derivative causality problem is solved. A state-space model of Stewart platform is provided at the end of their paper; however, the actuating elements which they discussed are linear DC motors, other than the hydraulic actuators in this article.

As regards to the bond graph based controller design of Stewart platform, Bera et al. reported a bond graph implementation of an overwhelming controller for a hydraulically driven planar Stewart platform.19 In their study, a complex inverse model was constructed from the bond graph model of the actual system, and it was used with an overwhelming controller to reject the disturbances and uncertainties. Davliakos and Papadopoulos developed a model-based impedance controller for a six-DOF electro-hydraulic Stewart platform mechanism.20 They used an impedance filter to create a new modified trajectory in order to reduce the effects of the nonlinear hydraulic dynamics. Simulations show that the controller has good performance in tracking typical desired trajectories.

The main objective of this article is the modelling of hydraulic Stewart-type simulator and presenting the graphic representation based on basic bond graph elements and by means of 20-Sim software. In this article, the model of the upper platform is built according to the modelling method of rigid body dynamics in Pacejka.21 The Eulerian equations for rigid body are represented as a well-known Eulerian Junction Structure. However, the dynamics of the other twelve rigid bodies (six pistons and six tubes) are not treated like the upper platform. Their inertial effects are equivalently treated as some forces to act directly on the upper platform according to Koebebakker.6 Using this method, the modelling process becomes relatively simple and involves less effort. Further, this model is established and simulated in 20-Sim software with BDF numerical method. This model can be used as an alternative modelling to supplement the multibond method. Based on this model, a position feedback and feed-forward compensation combined controller is designed for the hydraulic actuator, and besides a dynamic pressure feedback inner loop is added to further improve the control performance. So by simulation, relatively rational controller parameters are quickly obtained for later real-time implementation.

sec.title: Bond graph model of the upper platform
Dynamics and bond graph model of rigid body with two spherical joints
sec.p:
The connections between the upper platform and the six cylinders are all spherical joints. First, a spatial rigid body Rb with two spherical joint ports is shown in Figure 2. Symbols Pi and Pj are the spherical joint points at which Rb connects with other bodies. Two coordinate frames are established: one is inertial reference frame {b} and the other is body-fixed frame {p}. Figure 2.
Spatial rigid body with two spherical joint ports.

Applying Newton’s second law to the forces on Rb in frame {b} yields (1)mddtv=Fi+Fj+mg where m and v are mass and velocity of Rb, respectively, Fi and Fj the forces on the joint points Pi and Pj given by other bodies, respectively, and g the gravitational acceleration.

The Eulerian equation of Rb in frame {p} can be given as (2)Ip·ddtωp+ωp×Hp=Mi p+Mj p where Ip is the inertia matrix with its elements shown in equation (3), the superscript p represents the frame of {p}; ωp the angular velocity; and Hp the angular momentum, which is defined as Hp=Ipωp . The expanded expression of Hp is (3)Hp=[HxHyHz]=[Ixx-Ixy-Ixz-IxyIyy-Iyz-Ixz-IyzIzz][ωxωyωz]=[Ixxωx-Ixyωy-Ixzωz-Ixyωx+Iyyωy-Iyzωz-Ixzωx-Iyzωy+Izzωz]

Mi p and Mj p are the moments on body Rb from Pi and Pj, respectively, Mi p=ri p×Fi p , Mj p=rj p×Fj p , ri p and rj p are the position vectors of points Pi and Pj, respectively. Fi p and Fj p are the transformation forms of Fi and Fj in frame {p}, respectively, and the corresponding orthogonal transformation matrix is given based on the Z–Y–X Euler angles rotation as (4)T=[cβ·cγ-cα·sγ+sα·sβ·cγsα·sγ+cα·sβ·cγcβ·sγcα·cγ+sα·sβ·sγ-sα·cγ+cα·sβ·sγ-sβsα·cβcα·cβ] where c=cos , s=sin . Euler angles α, β and γ define the three sequential rotations: γ degrees around z-axis, next β degrees around y-axis and final α degrees around x-axis.

Equations (1) and (2) are further rewritten as (5)ddtv=1m(Fi+Fj)+g=1m([FixFiyFiz]+[FjxFjyFjz])+[00g]
(6)ddtωp=(Ip)−1(rip×Fip+rjp×Fjp−ωp×Hp)=([ Ixx−Ixy−Ixz−IxyIxx−Iyz−Ixz−IyzIxx ])−1 ×( [ 0−rizriyriz0−rix−riyrix0 ][ FixpFiypFizp ] +[ 0−rjzrjyrjz0−rjx−rjyrjx0 ][ FjxpFjypFjzp ] −[ 0−ωzωyωz0−ωx−ωyωx0 ][ HxHyHz ] )

Based on equations (5) and (6), the model for Rb can be established as shown in Figure 3.15,21 In this figure, Ai and Aj are the force vector transformation matrices from frame {b} to {p}. According to equation (4), the detailed realization of Ai or Aj is obtained as shown in Figure 4. In this figure, nine modulated transformers (MTFs) with the elements tij of matrix T as modulating signals are used to represent the transformations. r~i and r~j are the skew-symmetric matrices corresponding to ri p and rj p in equation (6). r~i or r~j can be represented with six MTFs as shown in Figure 5. These MTFs take rix , riy and riz (or rjx , rjy and rjz ) as their modulating signals. Figure 3.
Bond graph of rigid body with two spatial joint ports.
Figure 4.
Detailed realization of Ai or Aj.
Figure 5.
Detailed realization of r~i or r~j .

sec.title: Bond graph representation of the upper platform
sec.p:
For convenience of description, the above rigid body model of Figure 3 is divided into three submodels: Ji, R and Jj according to the dashed rectangles in Figure 3. So, the rigid body model of Figure 3 is redrawn as shown in Figure 6. In this way, the bond graph of rigid body with two spherical joints is reusable and further extensible. Figure 6.
Submodel form of rigid body Rb.

The two-port rigid body model in Figure 6 can be further extended into the upper platform model by adding four extra ports. The resultant model is shown in Figure 7. Without considering the inertial effects of any cylinder, forces F1, F2,…, F5 and F6 represent the actuating forces exerted by six cylinders. Every force is along the axial direction of each cylinder. Figure 7.
Bond graph of the upper platform.

sec.title: Bond graph of single hydraulic actuator
Dynamics analysis of hydraulic actuation system
sec.p:
Each hydraulic actuator is schematically shown in Figure 8. It takes the combination form of a two-stage servovalve and a single-rod cylinder. The two-stage servovalue includes a prepositioned two-jet flapper valve and another four-way spool valve as power stage. Figure 8.
Sketch of valve–cylinder combination.

Because the two-jet flapper valve has rapid response performance, its transfer function from input current i to spool displacement xv can be simplified as a second-order system22 (7)kvωn 2i=d2xvdt2+2ζωndxvdt+ωn 2xv where ωn is the natural frequency of the servovalve, ζ the damping ratio and kv the electronic gain.

The block diagram representation of equation (7) is shown in Figure 9, in which k1=kvωn 2 , k2=2ζωn and k3=ωn 2 . This block diagram can be added directly into the bond graph model of the hydraulic actuator in 20-Sim software. Figure 9.
Block diagram of input current to spool displacement.

The nonlinear flow formula of the servovalve can be given as8,22 (8)Q1={Cdwxv2ρ( ps-p1)(xv>0)Cdwxv2ρ(p1-p0)(xv<0)
(9)Q2={Cdwxv2ρ(p2-p0)(xv>0)Cdwxv2ρ( ps-p2)(xv<0) where Q1 and Q2 are the flows into the forward chamber and the return chamber, respectively; Cd the coefficient of the discharge; w the orifice area gradient of the servovalve; ρ the fluid density; ps the supply pressure to the servovalve; and p1 and p2 the forward and return pressures, respectively.

Considering the fluid compressibility and that the volumes of the two chambers of the cylinder have time-variable feature along with the piston’s motion, the flow continuity formula is given as (10)dp1dt=βeV1(xp)(Q1-cic( p1-p2)-A1dxpdt)
(11)dp2dt=βeV2(xp)(-Q2+cic( p1-p2)+A2dxpdt) where xp is the piston displacement, A1 and A2 the cross-section areas of the forward chamber and the return chamber, respectively, βe the effective bulk modulus, cic the internal leakage coefficient, V1(xp) the volume of the forward chamber, V1(xp)=A1(xp0+xp) , V2(xp) the volume of the return chamber, V2(xp)=A2(L-xp0-xp) , xp0 the initial position of piston and L the total stroke of the cylinder.

The hydraulic actuating force created by the cylinder is written as (12)Fh=A1p1-A2p2 where Fh is the value of hydraulic actuating force, which equals the load force FL on the piston as shown in Figure 8. The mass of the piston and rod is temporarily ignored herein, and its inertial effects as well as those of the tube will be discussed in ‘Consideration of the actuator inertial effects’ section.

The hydraulic actuating force Fh acts on the upper joint with its direction along the axis of the cylinder. The cylinder axial direction is denoted by unit vector n, n=[nx,ny,nz]T . By means of n, Fh is further decomposed along the x-, y- and z-axis of inertial reference frame {b} (13)Fi=Fh·ni (i=x,y,z)

Similarly, the velocity relation between the piston and the joint point of the upper platform is given as (14)dxpdt=va⋅n=vax⋅nx+vay⋅ny+vaz⋅nz where va is the joint point velocity of the upper platform, va=[ vax, vay, vaz ]T .

sec.title: Bond graph representation of hydraulic actuation system
sec.p:
According to equations (7) to (14), the bond graph model of hydraulic actuation system can be established as shown in Figure 10. This model takes the voltage U as input signal and includes five interconnected parts marked by dashed lines: feed-forward gain part, amplifier part, ‘Servovalve: i→xv ’ part, ‘Servovalve: xv→ F’ part and ‘Interface with upper joint’ part. Figure 10.
Bond graph of hydraulic actuation system: (a) detailed representation and (b) submodel form after wrapping.

In the feed-forward gain part (block diagram form), a gain module K4 before the amplifier is used to model the electronic gain of the preposed amplified circuit. The amplifier part is a gain module Ka to model the power amplified circuit from voltage to current. The ‘Servovalve: i→xv ’ part is previously discussed and same as Figure 9.

In the ‘Servovalve: xv→ F’ part, resistor elements R1, R2, R3 and R4 denote the fluid resistances of the orifices numbered with ‘1’, ‘2’, ‘3’ and ‘4’ in Figure 8. According to the flow formula given in equations (8) and (9), the flow formula of R1, R2, R3 and R4 are written in 20-sim as (15)R1:q1=cdwxv|p1-p0|sgn(p1-p0)
(16)R2:q2=cdwxv|ps-p1|sgn(ps-p1)
(17)R3:q3=cdwxv|ps-p2|sgn(ps-p2)
(18)R4:q4=cdwxv|p2-p0|sgn(p2-p0)

C-type storage energy elements C1 and C2 are fluid capacitors of the forward chamber and the return chamber, respectively. They are used to describe the flow-pressure relation in the cylinder caused by the fluid compressibility, and their formula are written as (19)C1:p1=βe(xp0+xp)A1∫Q1dt+p10
(20)C2:p2=βe(L-xp0-xp)A2∫Q2dt+p20 where L is the stroke of piston and p10 and p20 the pressures of the forward chamber and the return chamber, respectively. Considering a signal-controlled C-element to violate the energy conservation principle, the variable chamber volumes in the denominators of these two equations are replaced by a constant mean value.

In addition, R5 is used to model the internal leakage between the two chambers. Two effort sources Se(s) are used to denote supply pressure and return pressure, respectively. Two transformers TF1 and TF2 are used to convert the pressures of the two chambers into forces, respectively. Modules Kp and Kn are switch functions to control the opening and closing of the four orifices according to the input signal Xv, and their formula in 20-Sim are given as (21)Kp: output=0.5*(abs(input)+input))
(22)Kn: output=0.5*(abs(input)-input))

From equations (21) and (22), when input signal xv > 0, module Kp has nonzero outputs, but the output of module Kn is zero, orifices 2 and 4 are open, and orifices 1 and 3 are closed (Figure 8), then q2≠0 , q4≠0 , q1=0 and q3=0 , therefore Q1=q2 and Q2=q4 . Similarly, when input signal xv < 0, module Kn has nonzero outputs, but the output of module Kp is zero, therefore orifices 1 and 3 are open, and orifices 2 and 4 are closed. It results in q1≠0 , q3≠0 , q2=0 and q4=0 , which means Q1=q3 and Q2=q1 .

As regards to the connection with the upper platform, the effort variable (e) of the rightmost 0-junction in Figure 10 is the actuating force Fh of the cylinder. It is noted that the input ports of the upper platform’s submodel (Figure 7) are exactly this actuating forces, and each port is divided into three components: Fx , Fy and Fz . Therefore, the force Fh in Figure 10 is first connected to three MTFs (with the cylinder’s direction cosine as modulating signals) to be modulated into components Fx , Fy and Fz according to equations (13) and (14) before connecting to the upper platform.

sec.title: Consideration of the actuator inertial effects
sec.p:
The model presented in Figure 10 actually only considers the actuating forces of the six cylinders by ignoring the inertial effects of each cylinder.6 It is suitable to use this model to describe the occasion on which the mass of each cylinder is much less than that of the upper platform and can be ignored. If the mass of each cylinder is as large as necessary to be considered in comparison with that of the upper platform, the extra forces caused by the inertia of the cylinder should be considered. These extra forces can be divided into three parts:6 the gravitational force Fh , the inertial mass force Fa and the influence of its inertia FI . These forces will be worked out and projected equivalently on the connecting joint points of the upper platform. To do this, one of the cylinders is analysed below and its parameters are shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Schematic diagram of single hydraulic cylinder.

The gravitational force Fh is first projected. vac and vbc denote the velocities of the centroids of the piston and the tube, respectively. va denotes the velocity of the connecting joint point of the upper platform. Both vac and vbc can be stated as the functions of va as follows (23)vac=va+ωa×(−ran)=(I−ralPn)va=Jacva
(24)vbc=ωa×rbn=rblPnva=Jbcva where Pn=I-nnT , I is the identity matrix.

We define ma and mb as the masses of the piston and the tube, respectively. Based on equations (23) and (24), the gravitational force FG=mag+mbg is projected along the direction of va and the equivalent gravitational force FGe after projecting is (25)FG e=Jac Tmag+Jbc Tmbg=ma(I-ralPn) g+mbrblPng

Because gravitational acceleration g in equation (25) is a particular constant, force FGe can be represented with an effort source Se, which stands for g, to be added to the upper platform model after modulated by a MTF with a modulating signal of ma(I-ralPn)+mbrblPn . This representation can be seen in Figure 12. This figure is a further expansion of Figure 7 by adding the inertial effects of the six cylinders. Three 1-junctions are added between each Ji and Di (Figure 10) and they stand for the velocity of each joint point of the upper platform, namely vai . As mentioned above, the forces caused by the inertial effects of each cylinder will be equivalently projected on the joint point of the upper platform. Therefore, the bond graph representation of the inertial effects will be connected to these three 1-junctions. Figure 12.
Bond graph of the motion simulator.
Second, the inertial force Fa is generated by the mass of the piston, which can be described as (26)Fa=madvacdt
The projection of Fa on the connecting joint point of upper platform yields (27)Fae=ma(I−Pn+(l−ra)2l2Pn)dvadt +2ma(l−ra)ral3(nTva)Pnva +maral2| Pnva |2n
Equation (27) can be rewritten in a concise form as (28)Fae=Madvadt+h(va)

The second term h(va) in the right-hand side of equation (28) can be further rewritten as (29)e=h( f ) where e is the effort variable in bond graph, herein representing force vector h(va) acting on the joint point, and f the flow variable, herein f=va .

Therefore, equation (29) can be represented with a nonlinear three-port R-element and further added to the three 1-junctions standing for vai as shown in Figure 12. This means that the second term h(va) in the right-hand side of equation (28) has been already treated. However, the first term Madvadt will be discussed later.

Finally, the inertial force FI generated by the inertia of the piston and the tube can be treated by considering Lagrange and observing that their contribution to the kinetic energy is equivalent (30)FIe=(Ia+Ib)l2Pndvadt−2(Ia+Ib)l3(nTva)Pnva where Ia and Ib are the inertia matrices of the piston and the tube, respectively.
Equation (30) can be rewritten in a brief form as (31)FIe=MIdvadt+q(va)

The second term q(va) on the right-hand side of equation (31) can be further rewritten as (32)e=q(f) where the effort variable e represents the force on the joint point and f the flow variable, herein f=va .
Equation (32) can be represented with a nonlinear three-port R-element and directly added to the three 1-junctions standing for vai as shown in Figure 12.

The first term MIdvadt on the right-hand side of equation (31) can be incorporated with the first term Madvadt on the right-hand side of equation (28) since they have the similar forms, and the incorporating yields (33)F=(Ma+MI)dvadt
Figure 19.
Simulation and experiment results of pitch rotation.

Equation (33) can be represented with an I-element and directly added to the three 1-junctions standing for vai as shown in Figure 12. So far, the inertial influence of a single cylinder is completely modelled. The motion simulator includes six cylinders and the inertial effects of the other five cylinders can be treated in the same way.

sec.title: Control scheme of motion simulator
sec.p:
The whole simulator takes independent close-loop feedback control on each valve-controlled cylinder servo system. Its control diagram is shown in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Control scheme of the simulator.

For each valve-controlled cylinder servo system, a position close-looped control strategy is employed as shown in Figure 14. Herein, the proportional control algorithm (with proportional coefficient Kp) is used since it is more practical and effective. To increase the damping ratio, a dynamical pressure feedback correction inner loop is used within the outer loop. Meanwhile, a feed-forward compensation is also used to increase the dynamic response speed. Figure 14.
Sketch of each hydraulic servo system.

Based on the previous model in Figure 10 and the control block diagram of Figure 14, the detailed realization of valve-controlled cylinder servo system is shown in Figure 15. In Figure 15(a), Kf is the feedback module with gain kf . Figure 15(b) and (c) shows the contents of the dynamical pressure feedback module and the feed-forward compensation module, respectively. The terms k5, k6, k7 and k are all gain modules and Tp , Tx and τ are related parameters. For convenience of later description, this model is also wrapped into the form of submodel as shown in Figure 15(d). Figure 15.
Bond graph model of hydraulic servo system: (a) overall model; (b) dynamic feedback module; (c) feed-forward module; and (d) submodel form after wrapping.

sec.title: Bond graph model of the whole simulator
sec.p:
Based on the above analysis, the bond graph model of the whole simulator presented in Figure 16, the leftmost in this figure are six signal generators, which provide the desired signals of position and orientation of the upper platform. L1 , L2 ,…, L5 and L6 are position signals of six cylinders, which are created and output by the so-called Inverse Position Solution module. Kf is the gain used to convert the cylinder position signal to the voltage signal. These six identical Kf modules are for the six cylinders, respectively. For details of R, J1, J2,…, J5 and J6 refer to Figure 7 (further Figures 3, 4 and 5) and those of H1, H2,…, H5 and H6 refer to Figure 15. The interactions between each Ji and Hi refer to Figure 12 and its explanation. Figure 16.
Bond graph model of the whole simulator system.
Figure 20.
Simulation and experiment results of yaw rotation.

The Modulating Signal Generation module in the figure is used to compute and output all the modulating signals. It takes the real-time position and orientation signals of the upper platform as its inputs, calculates the direction cosines of the six cylinders as well as the coordinate transformation matrix of the upper platform, and outputs them to each Ji and Hi modules as the modulating signals, respectively. The R-elements, I-elements and MTFs standing for the inertial effects of each cylinder (see equations (25), (29), (32) and (33)) need modulating signals too, which are also from the Modulating Signal Generation module, but the signal lines are not drawn here for concise description. This Modulating Signal Generation module is completed in an equation form in 20-sim software.

sec.title: Example verification
sec.p:
An actual hydraulic Stewart-type motion simulator is selected as an example. This simulator’s solid model is shown in Figure 17, and its parameters are given in Table 1. From Table 1, it can be seen that the six actuators’ total mass is relatively large and their inertial effects should be considered. Using conventional methods, the modelling of this simulator involves the representation of all the 13 bodies and their interactions, and the resultant model will be complicated and time-consuming. Using the proposed method in this article, the bond graph model of the simulator is established with less effort according to Figure 16 using 20-sim software. Figure 17.
Diagram of the motion simulator.
Table 1.
Parameters of the motion simulator.
Subsystem Parameter values
Platform and cabin m = 6500 kg R = 2.71 m r = 1.59 m S = 0.64 m
s = 0.26 m Ixx = 9490 kg·m2 Iyy = 11,070 kg·m2 Izz = 12,880 kg·m2
Ixy = 0 kg·m2 Iyz = 0 kg·m2 Izx = 0 kg·m2
Actuator ma = 50 kg mb = 90 kg ra = 1.0 m rb = 1.1 m
Ia = 18.4 kg·m2 Ib = 36.6 kg·m2 L = 1.46 m
Hydraulic actuation system ps = 12 MPa P0 = 0.1 MPa A1 = 7.85 × 10−3 m2 A2 = 4.00 × 10−3 m2
Cd = 0.65 ρ = 900 kg/m3
βe = 6.9 × 108 Pa cic = 7 × 10−13(m3/s)/Pa
xp0 = 0.73 m p10 = 0 MPa p20 = 0 MPa kv = 1
ωn = 314 rad/s
ζ=0.7
k4 = 2 ka = 1
Controller Kf = 6.85 V/m Kp = 33.8 k5 = 7.85 × 10−3 k6 = 4.00 × 10−3
K7 = 1.27 × 10−4 Tp = 0.05 k = 0.03 τ = 1
Tx = 0.04

Some simulations are carried out to verify this model. Six single-DOF sinusoidal signals with 0.3 Hz frequency are selected as trajectories to be tracked: each rotation is α, β,or γ=0.5∘sin(1.884t) , and each translation is x, y, or z=1.5sin(1.884t) cm. According to Felez et al.,16 the model only includes Class 1 ZCPs with index = 0 and can be solved by BDF method. Simulation results are shown in Figures 18 to 23. In addition, experiments with the same parameter values as the simulation are finished on the actual simulator, and the experimental results are also added into these figures as the comparisons. In these figures, the curves numbered with 1 are the desired position or orientation signals. The curves numbered with 2 are the simulation results and those numbered with 3 are the experiment results. Figure 18.
Simulation and experiment results of roll rotation.
Figure 23.
Simulation and experiment results of heave translation.

It can be seen from these figures that the simulation results are close to experiment results with relative errors less than 10%. The worst case is the roll rotation with a relative error of 10%. In other cases, the relative errors are far less than 10%. In the simulation process, it is noticeable that the surge and sway translation curves (Figures 21 and 22) are not so smooth. The corresponding experiments also proved these cases, which fully validated the correctness of the bond graph model. Figure 21.
Simulation and experiment results of surge translation.
Figure 22.
Simulation and experiment results of sway translation.

The future work of this research is to convert this proposed model into a multibond representation form considering that multibond graph representation with multibonds is clearer and more efficient. Moreover, the new multibond graph representation approach will be further considered to model other types of parallel mechanism. In addition, a relatively simple proportional control algorithm with dynamic pressure feedback correction and feed-forward compensation is used in this article, thus more complicated and effective algorithms will be further developed and validated based on this bond graph model.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article developed a multidisciplinary unified bond graph model for hydraulically driven six-DOF motion simulator. Using a projection method, the inertial influence of each cylinder is modelled as the equivalent forces to be exerted on the upper platform, which enable us to consider the inertial effect of each cylinder under the condition that we need not establish each cylinder’s rigid body model just like the upper platform modelling. Therefore, the simulator model is simplified and much modelling efforts are saved.

A proportional control scheme with feed-forward compensation and dynamic pressure feedback correction is proposed for the simulator. Simulation and experiment demonstrated the feasibility and performance of the above model and control scheme. This modelling method can provide an effective reference to the modelling of other types of parallel mechanism.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research is supported by Project of Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China (DL09CB02), Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education of China (200802251020), Postdoctoral Research Fund (20070420160), Natural Science Fund of Heilongjiang Province (E201013) and Project of Harbin Research Fund (2008RFQXG004).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful to reviewers for their valuable remarks.
